channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Toll Rises by Hour in Haiti Amid Ruin Left by Hurricane Matthew
item.media:description: A woman in Gelée, Haiti, on Friday navigated the rubble after Hurricane Matthew. Some reports put the death toll at 800.
item.description: Some estimates said that more than 800 people had died in the storm, and passage to many areas remained blocked, thwarting efforts to help survivors.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Colombia’s President, Juan Manuel Santos, Is Awarded Nobel Peace Prize
item.media:description: Mr. Santos, center left, with Timoleón Jiménez, the FARC commander in chief, last month.
item.description: The committee recognized Mr. Santos “for his resolute efforts to bring the country’s more than 50-year-long civil war to an end.”
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: How U.S. Torture Left Legacy of Damaged Minds
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Beatings, sleep deprivation, menacing and other brutal tactics have led to persistent mental health problems among detainees held in secret C.I.A. prisons and at Guantánamo.
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO, SHERI FINK and JAMES RISEN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Sign of Thaw With Iran: American Cellphones Ringing in Tehran
item.media:description: Faryar Ghazanfari, a lawyer from San Francisco, was surprised to find that his cellphone worked in Iran, where he was visiting his grandmother.
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.description: AT&T’s partnership with an Iranian company suggests that promises President Hassan Rouhani made long ago of welcoming Western businesses may at last be coming true.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: John Kerry Calls for War Crimes Investigation of Russia and Assad Government
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Jean-Marc Ayrault, the French foreign minister, spoke in Washington on Thursday before a meeting on the Syrian crisis.
item.description: The remarks came one day before the Security Council is expected to vote on a call for a cease-fire in Aleppo, and the grounding of Russian and Syrian warplanes.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A General’s New Mission: Leading a Charge Against PTSD
item.media:description: Brig. Gen. Donald C. Bolduc, commander of American Special Operations Forces in Africa, tells soldiers that it is all right to get help for brain injuries and mental health problems.
item.description: It took 12 years for Brig. Gen. Donald C. Bolduc to deal with the mental trauma he sustained in eight combat tours. He doesn’t want others to wait.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Voices From a Worsening Afghan War
item.media:description: Afghan men prayed Thursday in Lashkar Gah, a southern Afghan provincial capital that has been surrounded by the Taliban for months.
item.description: Fifteen years after the American war in Afghanistan began, many Afghan families say the fighting and daily fear are worse than ever before.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Centuries of Buddhist Tradition Make Room for Bhutan’s First Law School
item.media:description: Michael Peil, the vice dean of the Jigme Singye Wangchuck School of Law, Bhutan’s first law school, spoke at a secondary school in Gyelposhing last month to recruit applicants.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: In a nation with a long-held tradition of resolving disputes through conciliation, a legal education is being melded with old values.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: News Analysis: For Britain’s ‘Brexit’ Bunch, the Party Just Ended
item.media:description: The steep drop in the value of British currency is a sign that the vote to exit the European Union has put Britain’s commercial relationships with the world on potentially perilous ground.
item.description: A sickening drop in the pound signals that all the illusions around the vote to leave the European Union have been shattered, and that Britain will pay a price.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Peace Prize Seen Not Necessarily for Achievements, but Hopes
item.media:description: President Juan Manuel Santos won the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday, days after Colombia rejected a peace deal he pursued.
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.description: Recent recipients — President Obama, the European Union and now President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia — suggest it is more an encouragement to persevere.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: In Splintered Georgia, 200 Political Parties Find Unity Against Russia
item.media:description: Nino Burjanadze campaigning this week in Tbilisi, Georgia. Ms. Burjanadze, who has been called a turncoat for meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, said Georgia “should not be a puppet of either the Russians or the Americans.”
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: With an election coming, there is no longer any question about whether the country should tilt toward the West or toward its neighbor to the north.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: No Hockey or J.Lo, but Vladimir Putin Still Gets 450 Roses for His Birthday
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow on Wednesday.
item.description: The Russian president celebrated turning 64 with a bouquet of flowers, one from each member of the State Duma, or lower house of Parliament.
item.dc:creator: SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

item.title: In Rare Encounter, a Private U.S. Delegation Visits North Korea
item.description: Last month’s trip, organized by the Richardson Center, suggested a possible opening with the world’s most isolated country.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Favorite Thanksgiving Recipes From Across Canada
item.description: Canada’s Thanksgiving, which takes place on the second Monday of October, features turkey, stuffing and televised football — and its own regional dishes.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN and IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Russia Seeks to Reopen Military Bases in Vietnam and Cuba
item.description: The Russian deputy defense minister said that the Kremlin was working to re-establish the former bases, which closed in 2002.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: After Hurricane Matthew, Devastation in Southern Haiti
item.media:description: Jérémie, Haiti, where 80 percent of buildings were destroyed by the storm.
item.description: The hurricane destroyed houses and left villages under several feet of water.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: American Chess Player Boycotts Championship in Iran Over Hijab Rule
item.media:description: A YouTube image of Nazi Paikidze-Barnes, a Russian-born Georgian-American and one of America’s top chess players.
item.description: Nazi Paikidze-Barnes, a women’s chess champion, said she would not attend next year’s women’s world competition because religious law would require her to wear a hijab.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Justice Dept. Is Asked to Review Chinese Company’s Hollywood Purchases
item.media:description: Wang Jianlin, chairman of Dalian Wanda Group, in Beijing in August.
item.description: A lawmaker wants an inquiry into acquisitions by Dalian Wanda Group, which are believed to have been made to try to influence how films portray China.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: China Seeks Tighter Grip in Wake of a Religious Revival
item.media:description: Ethnic Lisu heading to a Christian church in April in Fugong, in Yunnan Province. The Chinese government is expected to enact regulations tightening its oversight of religion in the coming days.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: The rules include restrictions on religious schools and limits on access to foreign religious writings, including on the internet.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: U.S. Set to Open a Climactic Battle Against ISIS in Mosul, Iraq
item.media:description: The body of an Islamic State fighter lay on the ground after the Iraqi Army repelled the militants’ attack outside the town of Qaiyara, near Mosul, on Tuesday.
item.description: Some former officials and aid groups worry that President Obama will begin a ground campaign without a comprehensive plan for what happens afterward.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER, ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Third Piece of Debris Confirmed to Be From Missing Malaysian Jet
item.media:description: A piece of debris identified by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau as having come from the left wing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
item.media:credit: Australian Transport Safety Bureau, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Australia said the debris had serial numbers and marks similar to those on another piece identified as part of the jet, which disappeared in March 2014.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: What in the World: You Say ‘Anguria,’ I Say ‘Cocomero’: Italy’s Many Dialects
item.description: The country has hundreds of local variations on language, each with its own quirks of pronunciation, inflection and vocabulary, which can make daily interactions confusing.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: What in the World: In Senegal, Absolution Comes With a Wing and a Prayer
item.description: In Dakar and other cities, men stand on street corners with cages of red-billed firefinches, which people buy and release to get rid of sins and anxiety.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on a New U.N. Chief
item.description: António Guterres, a former prime minister of Portugal, is next in line to take on the weighty job.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Don’t Intervene in Syria
item.description: With the cease-fire collapsed and horrific violence in Aleppo, American intervention might seem tempting. It’s still a bad idea.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN SIMON and JONATHAN STEVENSON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
